New policy which replaces the following document at Broomfield Hospital: 08021 Linen and curtains policy

data.text: Contents
Accessing, Delivery and Storage of Clean Linen and Curtains ..................................... 8
Introduction

All patients should be provided with appropriate and good quality bed linen and clothing items as required in accordance with infection prevention & control standards. In addition, all curtains, at windows, bed spaces and in bathrooms/shower rooms, should be standardised, of good quality, clean and free from damage.

The Trust has an obligation under the Health & Safety at Work Act to take reasonable steps to prevent the risk of infection to staff handling linen in accordance with the NHS Executive HSG (95)  Hospital Laundry Arrangements and HTM 01- 04 Decontamination of linen for health and social care.
The Trust is required to manage the risk of potential for harm to staff and damage to linen by a failure to separate sharps from dirty linen before it is placed in to laundry bags.
The Trust is required to ensure that it only purchases curtains that comply with the Furniture and Furnishings (Fire Safety) Regulations 1988 (as amended in 1989, 1993 and 2010).
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Ensure patients maintain their privacy and dignity rights by providing suitably sized and appropriate clothing items and curtains.
Meet infection prevention requirements and prevent contamination by ensuring that bed linen and curtains are changed appropriately in accordance with Trust infection prevention policies.

Provide guidance for the safe handling, disinfection and disposal of all used linen and curtains in accordance with NHS Choice Framework for local policy and procedures HTM 01-04 – Decontamination of linen for health and social care also known as “HTM 01-04”.
Provide guidelines for accessing linen and curtains at all times.
Definitions

table_items.text: Articles and garments made form linen or similar textile, such as cotton or manmade fibres, provided by the Linen Provider.
Linen items that are new, have been processed or are otherwise clean and have not yet been used for patient care.
All linen which is: Contaminated with excreta, blood or body fluids, or
Contaminated linen from an infectious patient who is known, or clinically suspected, to be infectious (for example salmonella, hepatitis A, B or C, open pulmonary tuberculosis, HIV).
Used Linen not classified as Infected Linen.

Linen that is deemed “not fit for purpose” before patient used. Examples of linen “not fit for purpose” are as follows: Tears or holes Stains visible before patient use Faded or worn fabric Damage items (such as patient gowns missing ties) Excessive creasing

The stock of linen required to service the needs of the Trust (i.e. in an out of hours capacity or major incident). There are 2 types of emergency linen supplies: Out of Hours Stock- Linen Contingency Stock- Linen

The agreed level of linen required for each individual ward/dept. This is assessed on a regular basis and reviewed annually to ensure that the level of linen provided is reflective of the ward/dept. need
Including launder privacy curtains, disposable curtains and shower curtains.
Linen items that are Trust owned, or special items (such as curtains, slings etc.) or patient owned that are laundered by the linen & laundry provider
Specialist clothing supplied by the linen provider and worn by theatre and other designated department staff.
The current Linen and Laundry company that delivers the service to the Trust.
Agreed contractual and operational performance, identifying responsibilities of the Trust and Linen Provider
The member of the Trust that has been agreed to manage the contract in all capacity, be point of contact for Trust staff to escalate issues and liaise with the onsite linen provider staff.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Committee responsibilities (i.e. Medicines Committees)

Infection Prevention and Control Committee (IPCC) is responsible for the review of this policy at least every two years, but more frequently if there are changes to Infection Prevention and Control Legislation or guidance. Promote evidence based Infection Prevention and Control practices in line with Trust policies Be responsible for the production of the policy and management procedures Work closely with linen services management and be responsible for informing Trust staff about any relevant changes to Infection Prevention and Control Legislation, or guidance regarding linen products especially anti- microbiological specifications, linen handling, linen change frequencies as well as providing appropriate training to staff.
Individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive)
The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for the implementation of this policy. The Chief Executive delegates this responsibility to the Director for Infection Prevention and Control.

The Director for Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC) has the responsibility to ensure there are adequate resources available to manage all aspects of infection prevention and control within the Trust.
Estates & Facilities Site Manager is responsible for ensuring robust systems, processes and adequate resources are in place to provide sufficient bed linen and curtains of good quality.

Director of Nursing is responsible for agreeing any changes of practice in the use of linen such as bed making procedures, agreeing types and curtain styles that are all in line with current British Standards, and ensuring that appropriate linen procedures are followed by all clinical staff.

Lead Nurses/Matrons  are responsible for ensuring all Ward/Departmental Managers & Ward Sisters/Charge Nurse in their areas are aware of and understand the Linen and Curtain Policy and that it is implemented into practice locally and within their areas of responsibility, as well as investigating failures to comply with the Linen Policy and ensure corrective action is taken to prevent a recurrence.

Trust Authorised Officer is responsible for managing the linen contract, review and produce performance reports regarding contractual and operational performance, highlighting KPI failures, meeting with the linen provider on a regular basis to review and investigate escalated contractual and operational issues, establishment and on-going review of the Linen Policy and approving changes to ward linen shelf levels and initiating appropriate action as part of the key performance indicators (KPI) for the Trust's Linen & Laundry Services specification.

Linen Provider Manager/Supervisor is responsible for managing an on-site team to deliver and collect linen in accordance with specified service level agreements, and inform the Trust authorised officer of any problems in the delivery of the linen service on a daily basis.
Domestic staff are responsible for changing curtains in accordance with the Cleaning and Infection Prevention policies, and maintain the Patient Clothing Service as outlined in the Linen Procedure

Ward/Departmental Managers & Ward Sisters/Charge Nurse are responsible for ensuring all staff in their areas are aware of and understand the Linen Policy and that it is implemented into practice locally and within their areas of responsibility ensuring all staff are aware of and comply with the policy, ensure that linen used is fit for purpose and that any items that are not, are returned to the linen provider using the correct reject system in place, identify linen quantities required for their area and agree any changes with the Trust Authorised Officer, and ensure that items that belong to their area are laundered through the personal bundle system appropriately to avoid loss.

The Procurement Department is responsible for ensuring that only the curtain specifications as agreed by the Director of Nursing are purchased, and escalating any requests for items outside of this specification to the Trust Authorised Officer.

Infection Prevention Team will work closely with the Trust authorised officer to Provide advice on new products and laundering procedures Provide advice and be consulted on all matters related to linen contracts and curtain changing frequencies Provide appropriate infection prevention training to Trust staff.

All staff have a legal obligation to take necessary measures to prevent the risk of infection of all linen (both clean & dirty, ensuring that only linen of a good quality is used for patients, following the correct and that the procedures for the use of clean linen, and handling and storage of soiled linen within this policy.
Patient dignity and privacy
Every effort should be made by the Trust to ensure that patient's privacy and dignity rights are met whilst under the Trust's care.
There are a number of linen items, including bed linen and patient clothing that are designed for specific sizes and purposes.
Staff must ensure that the appropriate items are used at all times to ensure patients have dignity.
Accessing, delivery and storage of clean linen and curtains
Each ward or department that require linen must have an agreed shelf level, which is agreed through the Ward Sister or Departmental Manager and the Trust Authorised Officer.
It is recognised that additional linen will be required from time to time in order to cope with infections on wards etc. and requests should be made in line with the Linen Procedure for each site.

It is recognised that specialised linen will be required for bariatric patients admitted on wards. Should patients require bariatric gowns the ward should request this in line with the Linen Procedure for each site.

It is also recognised that daily stock levels might need to be changed on a regular basis to reflect the patient activity. Requests for changes in levels should be made in line with the Linen Procedure as outlined for each site.
Linen is delivered to wards and departments Monday to Saturday by the linen provider within an agreed timeframe as detailed in the KPI agreement.

Clean linen will be delivered to and stored on wards and departments in identified facilities such as a store room, cupboard or trolley. These storage facilities should not be used to store any items other than clean linen. Linen must be kept off floors at all times the facilities must be kept clean and tidy to ensure easy and quick access at all times.

It is recognised that additional linen may be required when the linen room is closed. An emergency stock of linen is available on each site. Wards and departments can request linen out of hours in line with the Linen Procedure.

Emergency services are not permitted to utilise the on-site linen stock held in the Emergency Department to replenish the linen on the ambulance. Emergency Services must maintain their own supply of linen for ambulances.
Bed making
In order to assist in the attempt to reduce the possibility of contamination and cross infection, beds must be changed as outlined in the Linen Procedure, ensuring that :
All linen items must be changed when a new patient is admitted.
All linen items must be changed if the patient has been identified to have infections.
Rejected linen items

Some items of linen may be deemed not “fit for purpose” before they have been used and therefore must be rejected by placing the rejected linen in the appropriate colour coded reject bag (brown) as outlined in the Linen Procedure. Linen item can be rejected for the following reasons:
Tears or Holes in the fabric
Stains visible before patient use
Faded or worn fabric
Damage to the items (such as patient gowns missing ties)
Excessive creasing

Rejected linen should not be placed through the normal laundering process; the item not “fit for purpose” will not be taken out of the system and will be laundered, incurring additional expenditure to the Trust.
Rejected linen must not be placed through the Waste Streams (clinical or domestic waste). All linen items must be processed using the correct bagging procedure as outlined in the Linen Procedure.
Laundering linen

All soiled linen must be segregated accordingly using appropriate colour coded bags as outlined in the Linen Procedure. Bags should be securely fastened and should never be more than 2/3 full to conform to manual handling recommendations.
All soiled linen should be handled and bagged in such a way as to protect patients and staff from risk of contamination or injury and to avoid damage to laundry machinery.

Storage rooms are provided throughout the Trust for the storage of dirty linen awaiting collection. These must be used at all times. Dirty linen should not be stored in corridors or anywhere other than inside a designated disposal rooms.

Only linen must be sent to the laundry. Other items such as disposable or single use gowns, masks, gloves etc. should be removed and placed in the correct waste streams according to the waste segregation processes. Extra care must be taken to ensure that personal patient items such as reading glasses, mobile devices, watches and jewellery etc. are removed before bagging the linen. These items will not be retrievable once the soiled linen has been collected from the ward.

Infected or heavily soiled linen must be bagged in a water soluble red bag on the removal from the bed or the patient before placing into a white coloured bag to prevent the risk of spreading infections. Heavily soiled or infected linen for personal bundles should follow the same procedure and be placed in a water soluble red bag and then into purple bag as outlined in the linen procedure.

Infected or heavily soiled linen must not be placed through the Waste Streams (clinical or domestic waste). All linen items must be processed using the correct bagging procedure as outlined in the Linen Procedure.
Any items found within soiled linen such as equipment or sharps will be reported and investigated through the Trust incident reporting system.
Return to sender procedure

In order to ensure that Trust owned items and personal items are returned directly to the ward or domestics department, it is imperative that these items are laundered via the Return to Sender process as outlined in the Linen Procedure.
Any items laundered that need to be returned to a ward or department must be placed in a purple bag and have a completed Return to Sender ticket to include the following information:
The date the items were placed in the purple bag
The item descriptions (for example, curtains, tunic etc)
The quantities of the items contained in the purple bag
The name of the department, ward and/or persons the items are to be returned to
Linen staff will not collect Return to Sender items without a ticket present and completed fully as there is a significant risk of item loss to the owner should this information not be provided.
Special items such as reusable slings should also be laundered through this process. When completing the ticket, the item must be recorded as returned to the Manual Handling Department.

All linen items that are processed using the Return to Sender Procedure are sent and laundered at the owners own risk, due to the high laundering temperatures. Owners must be made aware of this risk before completing the process.

Return to Sender items are agreed to be processed within 72hrs of receipt of the items in the linen room on the site (not inclusive of weekends, bank holidays or national holidays). Once the items have been received, the on-site linen management will record the items being sent for laundering and will track the progress of the items until returned to the site.
Laundering and disinfection process

The laundering process must have a disinfection cycle in which the temperature of the load is maintained at 65°C (150°F) for not less than  minutes or preferably at 71°C (160°F) for no less than 3 minutes in line with the HTM 01-04.

For items that are not designed to laundered at high temperature and the chemical disinfection process, this process must still satisfy the requirements in the section ‘Disinfection of linen' set out NHS standard HTM 01-04.

All washing machines must comply with the recommended and relevant criteria defined in HTM 01-04. Laundering machinery should have the specified programming ability and accurate heat sensors to meet the required disinfection standards. Industrial machines having the capability to meet these requirements must be used. Wash temperatures should be subject to a monitoring system and heat sensing systems should be tested and calibrated at six weekly intervals. Records should be kept by the linen provider showing six weekly testing and calibration as a minimum standard.
All linen items, including Scrubs, must be laundered through the linen provider laundering process. Linen items supplied by the linen provider must not be removed from the hospital site.
Clean and new curtains

The Trust has agreed a standardised disposable curtain which meets fire retardant standards throughout its premises to promote a professional image whilst allowing a streamlined approach for the curtain changing programme.
Any new curtains to be purchased must comply with this standard. Any changes to the use and type of curtain must be approved by the Director of Nursing and the Infection Prevention Lead.
Paediatric wards are exempt from the standardised curtain in order to provide a child friendly environment, however these curtains must meet the required fire retardant standard.
In accordance with the national specifications for cleanliness in the NHS, curtains/blinds should be visibly clean with no blood and body substances, dust, dirt, debris, stains or spillages.

Curtains, including shower curtains, must be changed immediately when visibly soiled and during a terminal clean where required, or as part of the Curtain Change Programme as outlined in the Linen procedure.
Patient clothing

A small selection of patient clothing and footwear is stored and accessed by the Domestic team for use when patients are discharged without any available clothing to wear when leaving the hospital. Types, sizes and colours cannot be guaranteed to be in stock and not all items will be new.
The process for requesting patient clothing is the responsibility of the ward staff as outlined in the linen procedure.
Scrubs

Special clothing (e.g. theatre scrub suits, disposable headwear and specialised footwear) is issued, in line with infection prevention, for particular areas due to the nature of the work and should not be substituted with other items. Different colours of scrubs available through the linen provider can be used throughout the Trust to identify different departments as outlined in the Linen Procedure.

Scrubs available from the linen provider are not identified as a uniform, and therefore must be treated as a linen item. The scrubs must be laundered using the laundry and disinfection process in accordance with HMT 01-04.

Scrubs can only be worn in designated areas. While wearing disposable protective overcoats, scrub suits may be worn within the main hospital building. However, it is not acceptable to wear soiled scrubs or soiled footwear within public areas of the hospital buildings. Hats or masks must not be worn in public areas.
Scrubs must not be removed from the hospital grounds.

In accordance with the adverse weather planning, it may be necessary to provide emergency scrubs to designated wards and departments as a proposed action following a heat wave alert. This will be agreed with the Director of Nursing and Trust Authorised Officer, and will provide details of actions required regarding emergency scrubs (locations, duration of need etc.).
Risk of ligature

A ligature is any piece of clothing or cordage, or any item that can be tied or fastened around the neck, which could be utilised, as a tie or noose for the purpose of self-harm by strangulation or hanging when tied to an object. This can include linen items, such as strips of clothing or bedding, or ties from patient gowns.
Linen quality auditing and service performance
Both trust and linen provider will inspect the quality of linen provided, including delivery levels and times, in accordance with the agreed KPI's.
Contract performance meetings will take place on a regular basis with the Trust Authorised Officer and linen provider.
Staff at ward and department level are responsible for alerting Trust Authorised Officer if they experience shortages of linen or quality issues i.e. staining, torn at any time.
Any changes to contract must be agreed by the Trust Authorised Officer by way of Variation to contract as outlined in the Linen Procedure
Training requirements
Linen procedures are included in the Infection Prevention mandatory and corporate induction sessions.
Local induction also includes laundering processes, and safe handling of linen at ward level.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Adherence to policy regarding linen processes and compliance
Compliance with Linen specification KPIs Audit

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the EFM Governance Board, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policy and procedural guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Business Development Unit of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 1)
References
